title: النِّدَاءُ الْمُتَقَدِّمُ
description: Learn advanced vocative rules including calling nouns with أل (يا أيها), calling nouns possessed by ياء المتكلم (يا ربّ), and vocative of lamentation (المندوب).

notes.title: Calling Nouns with أل
content: In Arabic, you cannot directly call a noun with أل (*يَا الرَّجُلُ is incorrect). Instead, you must use أَيُّهَا (for masculine) or أَيَّتُهَا (for feminine) as an intermediary.
The structure is: يَا + أَيُّهَا/أَيَّتُهَا + noun with أل. The noun after أَيُّهَا is either تَابِع (follower) or بَدَل (substitute).
keyPoints: Cannot directly call noun with أل

notes.title: Analysis of يا أيها
content: يَا: حَرْف نِدَاء. أَيُّ: مُنَادَى مَبْنِيّ على الضَّمّ في مَحَلّ نَصْب. هَا: حَرْف تَنْبِيه (for alerting). The noun after is مَرْفُوع.
The noun following أَيُّهَا can be analyzed as: نَعْت (adjective), بَدَل (substitute), or عَطْف بَيَان. All analyses lead to رَفْع.

examples.arabic: يَا أَيُّهَا الْمُؤْمِنُ: المؤمنُ = بدل مرفوع
يَا أَيُّهَا الطَّالِبُ: الطالبُ = نعت مرفوع

notes.title: Calling Nouns with ياء المتكلم
content: When calling a noun that is possessed by the speaker (مُضَاف إِلَى يَاء المُتَكَلِّم), there are multiple options for the ending of the possessed noun.
Options include: keeping the ي (يَا رَبِّي), deleting ي with kasra (يَا رَبِّ), replacing with alif (يَا رَبَّا), or fatha without ي (يَا رَبَّ).
keyPoints: يَا رَبِّ - delete ياء, keep kasra

notes.title: Special Forms: أَبَت and أُمَّت
content: When calling one's father or mother, Arabic uses special forms: يَا أَبَتِ (O my father) and يَا أُمَّتِ (O my mother). The تَاء replaces the يَاء.
The تَاء can take different endings: يَا أَبَتِ (with kasra), يَا أَبَتَ (with fatha), يَا أَبَتَا (with alif). These are unique to these two kinship terms.

examples.english: O my father, why do you worship...? (Quran 19:42)
O my son, do not associate with Allah (Quran 31:13)

notes.title: Vocative of Lamentation
content: نِدَاء الْمَنْدُوب is calling someone in grief or lamentation, typically for the deceased. The particle used is وَا instead of يَا, and the noun ends with ـاهُ or ـاهَا.
The structure expresses sorrow: وَا زَيْدَاهُ (Alas, Zayd!). It can only be used for specific, known individuals, not general nouns.

notes.title: Summary of Vocative Patterns
content: Regular vocative: يَا + noun (يَا زَيْدُ). With أل: يَا أَيُّهَا + noun (يَا أَيُّهَا الرَّجُلُ). With ياء المتكلم: يَا رَبِّ. Lamentation: وَا + noun + ـاه.
The مُنَادَى can be: مَبْنِيّ على الضَّمّ (single definite), مَنْصُوب (مُضَاف or شَبِيه بِالْمُضَاف), or مَبْنِيّ في مَحَلّ نَصْب.

exercises.prompt: لَا يَجُوزُ نِدَاءُ الْمُعَرَّفِ بِأَل مُبَاشَرَةً، بَلْ نَسْتَخْدِمُ _____
exercises.promptEn: You cannot directly call a noun with أل, instead use _____

exercises.prompt: يَا أَيُّهَا الرَّجُلُ - أَيُّ هُنَا مُنَادَى مَبْنِيٌّ عَلَى _____
exercises.promptEn: يا أيها الرجل - أَيُّ here is مُنادى built on _____

exercises.prompt: يَا رَبِّ - هٰذَا نِدَاءُ الْمُضَافِ إِلَى _____ الْمُتَكَلِّمِ
exercises.promptEn: يا ربِّ - this is calling a noun possessed by the speaker's _____
Vocative of lamentation is used to express _____
The vocative particle in lamentation is _____

exercises.prompt: يَا أَبَتِ - التَّاءُ هُنَا _____ عَنْ يَاءِ الْمُتَكَلِّمِ
exercises.promptEn: يا أبتِ - the تاء here _____ the ياء of the speaker

exercises.answer: O (you) - used to call nouns with أل

exercises.prompt: O you (feminine) who - for calling feminine nouns with أل

exercises.answer: يَا أَبَتِ / يَا أَبَتَا / يَا أَبَتَاهُ
